title: 110_hr4100
content: The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new section on Instructional Level Assessment Pilot Program. This program aims to assess students' instructional levels. The Secretary will award grants to up to ten State educational agencies for pilot programs to assess students with disabilities below grade-level proficiency and provide quality instruction. Grants will be for a 3-year period, and States must submit an application for the grant. States must apply for a 3-year grant to assess students with disabilities below grade-level proficiency. To be eligible, a State must not need intervention in implementing requirements of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act and have implemented alternate assessments. States must apply for a 3-year grant to assess students with disabilities below grade-level proficiency. Eligibility requires the State to have implemented alternate assessments and provide guidance to selected local education agencies on student selection for the pilot program. The State must apply for a grant to assess students with disabilities below grade-level proficiency. The application must include guidance for local education agencies on student selection, assessment tools, data collection, and implementation of a response to intervention approach. Monitoring and oversight of the program is also required. The pilot program aims to ensure quality instruction for all students and oversight of local education agencies, including reviewing documentation by the IEP Team. The State must implement program elements for the pilot. The pilot program aims to ensure quality instruction for all students and oversight of local education agencies. In implementing the pilot, a State educational agency and participating local educational agencies must limit student participation to 0.5 percent of the total population assessed and ensure that the student's IEP Team has determined the appropriate assessment. The pilot program requires the appropriate assessment for students, parental consent, data-driven instruction, and examination of student data by the IEP Team. The pilot program requires assessments, student work, IEP progress notes, response to intervention data, teacher recommendations, and other relevant data to determine if a student is performing significantly below their grade level in reading or math. Additionally, scientifically-valid assessments must be administered based on the student's instructional level. The pilot program mandates administering scientifically-valid assessments at the student's instructional level in reading and math. The IEP Team must develop interventions to address identified gaps in the student's knowledge. The pilot program mandates administering assessments at the student's instructional level in reading and math. The data from these assessments cannot be used to determine student proficiency or school progress. Each local education agency must compile a report on progress. The pilot program requires assessments at the student's instructional level in reading and math. Local education agencies must compile reports on student progress towards grade level proficiency. State education agencies must submit annual reports to the Secretary. The pilot program requires assessments at the student's instructional level in reading and math. State education agencies participating in the pilot must submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing student participation and progress towards closing the gap between current grade level proficiency and instructional level proficiency. Data collected will be used to inform a report to Congress on student participation and changes in proficiency levels. The pilot program requires assessments at the student's instructional level in reading and math. State education agencies must submit annual reports detailing student participation and progress towards closing the proficiency gap. $5,000,000 is authorized for grants under this section for fiscal year 2008.
